edu.first.main

Class GamePeriods

  • java.lang.Object
    • IterativeRobot
      • edu.first.main.GamePeriods

  • public final class GamePeriods
extends IterativeRobot
    This class is called by the VM automatically for every game mode. It is meant to start all necessary functions, and is the gateway from the Java VM into your code. GamePeriods is final because the functionality it provides is through Robot Modes. Although the implementation and specifics about how RobotMode is used is up to the programmer, the usage of RobotMode is necessary. This does not detract from GamePeriods's usefulness because it contains all of the methods of GamePeriods and more. GamePeriods works by using a RobotModeSelector to select from modes. This allows the programmer to use one mode or multiple modes. The mode is selectable on the SmartDashboard under the key "Robot Mode". To change this functionality, edit this class so that updateMode() returns the mode you want to run. If you change the name of this class or the package after creating this project, you must also update the manifest file in the resource directory. (/resources/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF under "MIDlet-1") This class is not thread safe and should never be manually constructed, but by mandate (VM) its constructor needs to be public.
    Since:
    May 07 13

    • Constructor Detail

      • GamePeriods

        public GamePeriods()

    • Method Detail

      • robotInit

        public void robotInit()
        Initializes the robot. Is run once at the start of the robot's execution cycle, but never again. Effectively should "start the robot", in whatever context it happens to be in.

      • disabledInit

        public void disabledInit()
        Initializes the disabled mode of the robot. Usually, this method "turns off" the functions of the robot, like background threads and motor controllers. Every time disabled is run, the RobotMode is updated. This only happens during the disabled period.

      • disabledPeriodic

        public void disabledPeriodic()
        Runs periodically during the disabled period. In the context of IterativeRobot, "periodic" means 50 times per second, or 50Hz. It is run every 0.02 seconds. This is not guaranteed, and is only run once every time the DriverStation sends packets. It can be roughly assumed that it runs at 50Hz, but should not be depended on.

      • autonomousInit

        public void autonomousInit()
        Initializes anything needed for the autonomous period of the robot.

      • autonomousPeriodic

        public void autonomousPeriodic()
        Runs periodically during the autonomous period. In the context of IterativeRobot, "periodic" means 50 times per second, or 50Hz. It is run every 0.02 seconds. This is not guaranteed, and is only run once every time the DriverStation sends packets. It can be roughly assumed that it runs at 50Hz, but should not be depended on.

      • teleopInit

        public void teleopInit()
        Initializes anything needed for the teleoperated period of the robot.

      • teleopPeriodic

        public void teleopPeriodic()
        Runs periodically during the teleoperated period. In the context of IterativeRobot, "periodic" means 50 times per second, or 50Hz. It is run every 0.02 seconds. This is not guaranteed, and is only run once every time the DriverStation sends packets. It can be roughly assumed that it runs at 50Hz, but should not be depended on.

      • testInit

        public void testInit()
        Initializes anything needed for the test period of the robot.

      • testPeriodic

        public void testPeriodic()
        Runs periodically during the test period. In the context of IterativeRobot, "periodic" means 50 times per second, or 50Hz. It is run every 0.02 seconds. This is not guaranteed, and is only run once every time the DriverStation sends packets. It can be roughly assumed that it runs at 50Hz, but should not be depended on.
